comments.body:
Hi,

The problem here is the localization is defined in the Core project. Actually, it's something related to presentation. We did it like that to allow you to use localization code in application and domain layers too.

hi Hikalkan，

thanks for your reply, I meant web project reference core will be caused domain layer exposed to presentation layer. Someone maybe use domain class directly.

You're right. It can be a potential issue. That's why I suggested to create a project like Core.Shared.

It's not infrastructure layer. It just stores some code (mostly consts) shared accross the entire solution. It does not depend on 3rd-party libraries and does not implement any service used in domain or application layers (it can not because it has not a reference to those projects).

title: webapi without ajax occurred csrf
body:
I an using webapi for exporting excel (return HttpResponseMessage ), client is post; Then it notice me antiforgerytoken validation error, even I added @Html.AntiForgeryToken()  into the form.  so I could only add [DisableAbpAntiForgeryTokenValidation] on it.

What's another idea for solving the problem?
author: WilCameronP

comments.body:
Check browser's network tab to see if anti forgery token is sent.
I didn't understand it well, did DisableAbpAntiForgeryTokenValidation solve the problem?

It's because Web API can not recognize form values. It expects antiforgery token be sent in the header.
If you would make an ajax call, ABP automatically adds it to the header. But in a non-ajax request, it can not do it.
In MVC, it's possible, because MVC can better handle form values. But Web API is designed to bind HTTP body to model and we can not directly get antiforgery token from form like MVC.
I suggest you to make it via an MVC action rather than a Web API, if possible. Otherwise, you should handle anti forgery manually.
I think I got it. Thanks a lot

satisfaction_conditions: Explanation of why Web API fails to validate the anti-forgery token in non-AJAX form submissions

title: Why Application Services and Repositories are registered as transiente in IoC?
body:
Hello @hikalkan ,

In first place, congrats for your great work!

A wanna know, why services and repositories are registered as transient? As the service and the repository do not keep state, there is no need for them to be transients, and could be registered as Singleton thus avoiding the working instantiation every use. What do you think?

Thanks,
author: thiagoburgo

comments.body:
Hi,

It's always suggested to register dependencies as transient if no good reason. We should use singleton carefully since singletons should care about multi-tenancy. Also, a dependency of a singleton becomes singleton for that instance.

It's safer and simpler using transients.
Object creation has not much performance/memory impact.

As a brief, it's considered as a better/best practice. You can search web for more detailed answers.

Ok, fair enough,  

But if I wanna change default IoC registration in ABP, I need do it manually or I can set default behavior for all ApplicationServices/Repositories?

Thanks,
There is no direct way of changing it and there is no plan to add such an option. I suggest to not change it.

satisfaction_conditions: Explanation of why transient registration is preferred over singleton for stateless services in IoC
Clarification on whether default IoC registration behavior can be modified in ABP
Comparison of transient vs singleton tradeoffs in dependency injection contexts

author: a-merson

comments.body:
Hi,

Call Release whenever it's possible. As better, use ResolveAsDisposable in a using statement.
But.. if your resolving object is Singleton.. then releasing has no effect actually. So, you may not call Release in that case. But call Release even in that case wherever it's possible (you may change Singleton to Transient in the future, for example).

title: The operation cannot be completed because the DbContext has been disposed...
author: natiki

comments.body:
Hi, This is about lazy load of EF. Alternative solutions: 1. You can make GetLocationMappings method virtual, like: 
public virtual GetLocationMappingsOutput GetLocationMappings(GetLocationMappingsInput aInput)
Thus, ABP can implement UOW for this method, and session will be usable in this method. If you did use this class over an interface, it was not needed. This works but also implement 2nd solution: 1. You can select LocationMappingTableModel included Countries. This is better than 1st solution (Actually, you should make it virtual anyway). Because, in first solution, EF will make a db query for each contry and this is a performance killer. This known as N+1 problem. When you Include Contries, it will execute just one query. To implement it, You can add a method to your repository named GetAllListWithCountries() and in that like this: 
return GetAll().Include(l => l.Country).ToList();
If you have added referenced to EntityFramework nuget package to your application layer and made GetLocationMappings virtual, then you can replace this line: List locationMappings = _LocationMappingRepository.GetAllList(); wtih this one: List locationMappings = _LocationMappingRepository.GetAll().Include(l => l.Country).ToList();; Thus, you don't need to create a new repository method. --- I also have some advices: - EmEntityCommon and EmEntityBase classes should be abstract as I understand. - LocationMappingTableModel is not a good name. Why do you postfix with TableModel? If you want to implement DDD, your entities are Entity, not table model. LocationMapping is enough. If you really like, LocationMappingEntity is better. But if you dont want to implement DDD, it's OK. - Your GetLocationMappings method can be much more smaller if you map LocationMappingTableModel to LocationMappingDto. AutoMapper can do nested mappings.

Thanks for using it :)

As I understand, it worked.

As I see your codes, there is no need for virtual since you are using application service over interface. I did not understand it but I don't see all codes. What RetrieveAllLocationMappings() does?

I'm considering to add an Inlcude method to repository but EF and NHibernate differently implements it. NHibernate does not support multiple include but EF supports it. If you will never change EF, than reference EF from application layer and use GetAll().Include(...). If you don't like it, you can extend IRepository for your project easily. Because I can not promise when I add it to ABP :)

Hi,

Yep things started working once I used ILocationMappingAppService in the controller. What I don't understand is why UOW failed when I mistakenly had **LocationMappingAppService** as the variable type?

```
 private readonly LocationMappingAppService _LocationMappingAppService;
```

Hi @natiki,

It's easy. ABP uses dynamic proxying and non-virtual methods of a concrete class can not be proxied (can not override to add a dynamic behaviour). So, make your method virtual if you directly use the class. For interfaces, it's different. All methods of an interface can be proxied.
